Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Constraint Consistent, Task-Based Musculoskeletal Control Framework for Human Motion Synthesis and Immediate Feedback

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this research is to create a cyber-human framework that advances both robotics and biomechanics, by deepening our scientific understanding of human motor performance dictated by musculoskeletal physics and neural control, in order to assist clinicians in quantifying the characteristics of a subject's motion and designing effective motion training treatments. Current technologies do not permit detailed motion reconstruction in real time, which limits their use in clinical settings. This work will combine theory with software, hardware and sensing technology to synthesize human motion with dynamic, actively controlled subject-specific musculo-skeletal models and to provide real-time visual feedback to a human subject. The project will deliver open-source algorithms and metrics for quantifying human performance and for understanding the underlying motion characteristics that modify these metrics. The capabilities developed in this project will have a transformative impact on society by enabling real-time human motion synthesis, with potential applications in rehabilitation, physical therapy, human-robot interaction, kinesiology and occupational biomechanics. The new control framework and models, validated by motion capture experiments, will be disseminated to researchers through an online repository. Integration of the research with educational activities will equip involved undergraduates and underrepresented students with new insights and tools for developing future engineering research in a minority serving institution.

Project outcomes will include: (1) computational models of the human musculoskeletal system for task-based control; (2) integrated performance metrics for motion characterization based on a subject's physiological constraints; and (3) control and simulation algorithms to synthesize movement using biomechanical models that accurately match experimental data, compensate for measurement errors, and visualize the model and its motion in real time. To these ends, task-based models of human motion will first be created. Motion capture experiments will be conducted to validate the model and to fine tune subject-specific parameters. The resulting computational platform will then be used to determine long-term performance statistics and metrics to efficiently characterize human motion. In the second phase, robust control and simulation algorithms will be integrated with the computational system to synthesize movement using biomechanical models. The framework will be used to identify feasible modifications to improve subject-specific motion characteristics. Finally, these criteria will be integrated into a feedback mechanism that will visually suggest modified trajectories for optimal motion to the subject.

Institution.Name: California State University-Long Beach Foundation
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: CALIFORNIA STATE UNIVERSITY, LONG BEACH RESEARCH FOUNDATION

Performance_Institution.Name: California State University Long Beach Research Foundation

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this proposal was to develop a cyber-human system that uses sensory information along with computer models of human running to characterize a person's locomotion, to provide multi-modal feedback signals to modify and improve human motion over time. More specifically, the following was performed: (i) modeling human-cyber dynamic interaction in a tunable, unified framework, (ii) verifying and validating the biomechanical model, feedback modalities, and cyber-physical system based on human subjects? data, and (iii) developing performance metrics for characterization of locomotion based on a subject's physiological constraints and ability in sensing. These steps provides an intuitive and long-term solution to instruct movement changes. Providing intuitive and subject-specific alterations to gaits has broader impact potential to help retard the progression of musculoskeletal diseases or improving gait performance in individuals with musculoskeletal disorders.

The proposed cross-disciplinary collaborative research was at the intersection of robotics, machine learning, biomechanics, motor control and learning, and haptics. In addition to computation, the proposed human-cyber system uses current hardware and sensing technology to integrate modeling and simulation of human physical systems with real-time feedback. The project delivered metrics for characterizing running performance and provided real-time analysis techniques for the purposes of improving running mechanics that translate into improved running performance and health. The collaborative components of the project integrated subsystems for experimental testing, quantitative evaluation, optimization, and human learning of optimized running parameters.

The developed human-cyber system will advance scientific understanding of mutual interaction between humans and wearable robotic systems. Reducing injuries due to running, through better understanding of causation, would also provide a significant societal benefit. Improved ability to identify and correct risky running behaviors would have broad impact, as over 10% of Americans run regularly, with over half estimated to suffer running-related injuries annually. Providing intuitive and subject-specific alterations to gaits has a great potential to help retard the progression of musculoskeletal diseases and to improve gait performance in individuals with musculoskeletal disorders.

 


Last Modified: 05/31/2019
Modified by: Emel Demircan
